This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed in 7 days if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.
@dcelasun Hello. Sorry, but we cannot create feature for another languages, because we have no time. Can you say what I must to do to speedup merging PR to the master branch? Thanks.

Thanks for the PR. Few points:

- If you are adding `UnmarshalJSON`, please also add `MarshalJSON`.
- `strconv.Unquote` shouldn't be necessary.
- Please add tests.

OK, finally got a chance to look into this. The lack of another language is unfortunate, but it's not a deal breaker.

My only concern is `NullInterceptor`. Can we get rid of it? If the user doesn't pass any interceptors, we shouldn't call any. There should be no default interceptors.
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed in 7 days if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.

Hello. Without NullObject(NullInterceptor) code will be more complicated with if/else conditions(if interceptor set do first case, if not - second case). So, NullInterceptor is only a proxy to original handler, and do code more readable and easy to support/understand.
I understand that, but the additional `if/else` will better for performance in the default case which is no interceptors.
Okay, I understand your position. Maybe you have performance tests to check degradation after my feature? Is 1-2ns a critical impact on performance?
It's not a critical impact, but it's an avoidable impact just the same.
So without removing NullInterceptor you will not merge PR?

I don't see why this needs to be so confrontational. Every change to the codebase is something *we* have to maintain, usually indefinitely. So the barrier for entry for any new feature must be high. This PR is already weakened by its single language, out-of-spec nature so the least it could do is have *zero impact* on users who are not using this feature (which is the default case). When zero impact requires such a small and basic change (if/else) I don't understand your resistance towards it.

So yes, please make the change. Thank you.
Okay, thanks, I will fix it. But it will be like spagettie code :)

> * If you are adding `UnmarshalJSON`, please also add `MarshalJSON`.
Fixed.
> * `strconv.Unquote` shouldn't be necessary.
It's necessary, because value which passed to UnmashalJSON looks like `"SOMEVALUE"`, and we must remove this quotes to prevent "not a valid BLABLABLA string" from `ENUMNAMEFromString` function.
> * Please add tests.
Tests added. @dcelasun , can you say why pipelines are broken? I cant find any info about my tests there.

Thanks.

Sorry for noticing this so late and maybe I'm missing something, but why is this PR needed? The generated code already has `MarshalText` and `UnmarshalText` which work for `json.Marshal` and `json.Unmarshal`, see [here](https://play.golang.org/p/jnPa-TUzfis) for example.
Perhaps @apocolipse has some thoughts as he was one of the last Swift contributors. If there's anything I can do to help get this merged then please let me know.
This issue is no longer stale. Thank you for your contributions.
Not sure why multiple builds are failing, but it's highly unlikely it has anything to do with this change.

This issue has been automatically closed due to inactivity. Thank you for your contributions.
There's also #2007 ... may I ask to cross-review each others change, resolving any potential interferences?
There's also #2030 ... may I ask to cross-review each others change, resolving any potential interferences?

Dear @cfriedt I've just reviewed your change and I'm not certain if it is correct. Could you motivate your change further?

In my understanding, *all* init methods in the constructor `TMemoryBuffer(uint8_t* buf, uint32_t sz, MemoryPolicy policy = OBSERVE)` from existing memory will move the internal `rBound_` and `wBound_` up by `sz`. In the case of `OBSERVE` or `TAKE_OWNERSHIP` this happens in `initCommon()` whereas in the case of `COPY` this (probably, I did not follow all variables in detail) happens in `write()`.

Your PR changes this behavior. I can not say with certainty if or why the current behavior is correct, but I'm under the impression that the current implementation was written consistently with a certain intention in mind. And your PR breaks this consistency.

Or am I on the wrong track? Feedback welcome!

> There's also #2007 ... may I ask to cross-review each others change, resolving any potential interferences?

The two changes are unrelated. My change is foremost for better readability of the code. My change also introduces a difference in the allocation size of buffer enlargement. The current implementation computes this based on a relatively hard to understand formula. My change always allocates the next larger power of two, so essentially it doubles the buffer whenever the size is exceeded.

I can not say that my allocation policy is generally better. But it is hopefully easier to understand and maintain.
Nice!

> Or am I on the wrong track? Feedback welcome!

I think there is some conflation about whether `wPos` (and by extension `wBase_` and `wBound_`) has any bearing on whether or not the buffer is writeable.

`wPos` does not determine if the buffer is writeable (in terms of permissions). It's `owner_` that is responsible for that, as evident in `TMemoryBuffer::ensureCanWrite()`.

It's possible that there are conflicting semantics that are trying to accomplish the same thing as well.

But certainly, this unblocked me when I passed a pointer to an externally created buffer and could not write to it.

I can point you to a gtest example that demonstrates the issue if you like.
I also agree #2007 is unrelated.
Maybe stupid question but what exactly made this (minorish) patch necessary? Because there seem to be no known errors?

Originally I had an issue in CentOS 6, and later it appeared also in another OS version but I do not recall the details. It may have been CentOS 7 or MinGW build. I can not easily reproduce it without a larger rebuild. But I got reproducibly failing builds without this change on certain (older) versions of gcc.
If you feel this is not sufficient reason to merge then feel free to close the PR. I do not mind maintaining a local patch, and I can reopen the PR when the issue comes up for me again.

> I can not speak for other people and I don't know what has been discussed so far. However my concern is not about buffer ownership. I quote the relevant section:
> 
> ```c++
>     rBound_ = buffer_ + wPos;
>     // TODO(dreiss): Investigate NULL-ing this if !owner.
>     wBase_ = buffer_ + wPos;
> ```
> 
> So `wPos` is used to move `rBound_` and `wBase_` forward to the end of the buffer in all cases where `TMemoryBuffer` is constructed from existing memory. This makes certain sense to me, because its likely that users do not want to overwrite existing data.

What if there is no existing data to overwrite? Then the buffer *always* has zero bytes available for writing.

I think I'm beginning to see your point though; by fixing one use case, it breaks another.

Just to clarify, the use case that I have which is currently broken is this:
* a pre-allocated, fixed-size buffer is passed in
* The TMemoryBuffer should take ownership of the pre-allocated buffer
* no data has been written to the buffer
* all subsequent writes to the TMemoryBuffer fail, because `wBase_ == wBound_`

The use case that you are saying would be broken by this change is:
* a pre-allocated, fixed-size buffer is passed in
* The TMemoryBuffer should only observe the pre-allocated buffer
* irrelevant whether data has been written to the buffer or not
* all subsequent writes to the TMemoryBuffer fail, because `wBase_ == wBound_`


> I'm more than happy to get educated on the meaning of `rBound_` and `wBase_` and why you think the current implementation is incorrect. But at least from my limited understanding I am not convinced that this change is correct.

Is it possible that the correct line should be the following? From what I can tell, it fixes both uses cases listed above.
```
initCommon(buf, sz, policy == TAKE_OWNERSHIP,  ( policy == TAKE_OWNERSHIP ) ? 0 : sz );
```

I can confirm that without this patch TMultiplexedProcessor does not work.

BTW. thanks for that TMultiplexedProcessor. I'm writing thrift server running on iOS and this came just in time! I'll write an issue and pull request soon to fix some problems in swift generator/library.

> I can confirm that without this patch TMultiplexedProcessor does not work.
> 
> BTW. thanks for that TMultiplexedProcessor. I'm writing thrift server running on iOS and this came just in time!

Thanks for taking a look at this functionality ðŸ‘

Hi guys. I would like to implement interceptors for java but first I want to discuss a general approach with you.
I want to implement interception chain like in gRpc https://grpc.github.io/grpc-java/javadoc/io/grpc/ServerInterceptor.html

If we project this solution on current codebase of Thrift I think the simplest thing will be to change ProcessFunction interface.
https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/master/lib/java/src/org/apache/thrift/TBaseProcessor.java#L38 it is called here but with raw inputs and then does some preprocessing inside https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/master/lib/java/src/org/apache/thrift/ProcessFunction.java#L21-L35

So if we move a part of logic from ProcessFunction to TBaseProcessor and call  fn.TBase getResult(I iface, T args) from TBaseProcessor it will give me an opportunity to decorate ProcessFunction with interceptors. In general the approach will be the same as with gRPC.

https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/master/lib/java/src/org/apache/thrift/ProcessFunction.java#L81

What do you think @dcelasun 
Thanks in advance.

> This change is going into 0.13.0, 

Will it? We usually don't do that unless we have a /really/ good reason (and someone who's willing to prepare such a release).

> I will also PR into master, depending on feedback from the team.

That would be the preferred way, yes.

@Jens-G Thanks for the reply! Trying to read between the lines here. So we're saying performance is not a big enough reason to patch and we want users to take on the next major version? I'm fine with that, but master has these breaking changes which make adoption difficult:

```csharp
public abstract class TTransport : IDisposable
...
        public abstract void UpdateKnownMessageSize(long size);
        public abstract void CheckReadBytesAvailable(long numBytes);
```

OT has its own TTransport (for some reason): https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-dotnet/blob/master/src/OpenTelemetry.Exporter.Jaeger/Implementation/InMemoryTransport.cs

Is there guidance somewhere on how to implement the `UpdateKnownMessageSize`/`CheckReadBytesAvailable` API?

My hope here was a small patch to 0.13.X for people on the existing API using it in high-volume scenarios and then also put into master for the next major (whenever people decide to upgrade).

Here are some performance numbers with and without this change (see `Allocated` column):

Before:
``` ini

BenchmarkDotNet=v0.12.0, OS=Windows 10.0.18363
Intel Core i9-9880H CPU 2.30GHz, 1 CPU, 16 logical and 8 physical cores
.NET Core SDK=3.1.101
  [Host]     : .NET Core 3.1.2 (CoreCLR 4.700.20.6602, CoreFX 4.700.20.6702), X64 RyuJIT
  DefaultJob : .NET Core 3.1.2 (CoreCLR 4.700.20.6602, CoreFX 4.700.20.6702), X64 RyuJIT


```

| **JaegerExporter_Batching** |               **1** |         **10000** |    **146.5 ms** |   **2.92 ms** |   **4.63 ms** |          **-** |         **-** |     **-** |   **6.74 MB** |               **1.0000** |                **-** |
| **JaegerExporter_Batching** |              **10** |         **10000** |  **1,442.4 ms** |  **74.31 ms** |  **85.58 ms** |  **8000.0000** |         **-** |     **-** |   **65.3 MB** |               **2.0000** |                **-** |
| **JaegerExporter_Batching** |             **100** |         **10000** | **14,192.9 ms** | **216.25 ms** | **180.58 ms** | **81000.0000** | **1000.0000** |     **-** | **650.91 MB** |               **4.0000** |                **-** |

  [Host]     : .NET Core 3.1.2 (CoreCLR 4.700.20.6602, CoreFX 4.700.20.6702), X64 RyuJIT
  DefaultJob : .NET Core 3.1.2 (CoreCLR 4.700.20.6602, CoreFX 4.700.20.6702), X64 RyuJIT


```

|------------------------ |---------------- |-------------- |------------:|----------:|----------:|------:|------:|------:|-----------:|---------------------:|-----------------:|
| **JaegerExporter_Batching** |               **1** |         **10000** |    **153.3 ms** |   **3.43 ms** |   **6.10 ms** |     **-** |     **-** |     **-** |  **256.76 KB** |               **1.0000** |                **-** |
| **JaegerExporter_Batching** |              **10** |         **10000** |  **1,511.4 ms** |  **29.43 ms** |  **41.26 ms** |     **-** |     **-** |     **-** |  **438.62 KB** |               **2.0000** |                **-** |

This issue has been automatically closed due to inactivity. Thank you for your contributions.

@dcelasun @bforbis or anyone else who has npm maintainer access - can you please fix the state of thrift 0.13.0 as published to npm? It seems to have mistakenly been published using https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/master/lib/js/package.json when all prior versions were published using https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/master/package.json, which properly includes and references both the browser and Node.js runtimes in ways that browser and Node.js builds can both understand. I am guessing that this mistaken publishing happened first, prompting this PR, when the real fix would be to republish with the correct package.json at the root.

This has broken all Node.js projects using Thrift for the past several months - for instance, the 'hello.js' example included in the npm Readme. But everything Node trying to require 'thrift' after installing it via npm will get the same error regardless:

```
{ Error: Cannot find module 'thrift'
    at Function.Module._resolveFilename (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:582:15)
    at Function.Module._load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:508:25)
    at Module.require (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:637:17)
    at require (internal/modules/cjs/helpers.js:22:18) code: 'MODULE_NOT_FOUND' }
```

Can you please republish 0.13.0 immediately to correct this? It would be greatly appreciated by those of us trying to stay up to date with Node.js projects, and would make this project work again for any newbies trying to work with the examples.
Unfortunately I don't have npm access. cc @jeking3 @Jens-G
Is that related to / superseded by THRIFT-5120 maybe?

I'm not really an expert, but I think this PR supersedes THRIFT-5120. THRIFT-5120 uses Node 8.x which since January 2020 is EOL. I think it may be better to go for the currently supported Node versions, or what do you think?

It seems to me that your change broke CI (i.e. linux with /usr/bin/python = 2.x, /usr/bin/python3=3.x).  If I revert your change, CI is working again, but that breaks --with-py3.

Mmmh ... `ninja: build stopped: subcommand failed.`

https://travis-ci.org/github/apache/thrift/jobs/660828704?

@janosvitok  `--with-py3` is there to enable python 3 support.

Prior to this patch, `configure` was failing to detect python3 support and would fail even when explicitly passing `--with-py3`.

Upon inspection, it was pretty obvious that `configure` would only accept a Python 2 version when specifying `--with-py3`, which is not the desired behaviour. To me, it seemed very clearly to be a typo. I only have python3, since python2 is now deprecated.

OS is Ubuntu Bionic.

However, this seems the be completely OS independent.

> UpdateKnownMessageSize/CheckReadBytesAvailable API

see THRIFT-5021 and THRIFT-5027

>That's KB not MB!

I agree on the alloc numbers (great!), but why is it 7% slower?

> release process

https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/master/doc/ReleaseManagement.md

What I see in docker ubuntu image is: with your patch python3 is not detected.
This is because /usr/bin/python returns Python 2.7.x and the rest is skipped.
In this case configure should check and find /usr/bin/python3 and/or /usr/bin/python3.6

What is your operating system and how did you install python so I can try to reproduce?

It is clear that there are two kinds of setup that are not properly handled:
1. both python 2 and 3 installed (the docker ubuntu case): /usr/bin/python is 2.x, /usr/bin/python3 is 3.x
2. only python 3 is installed (your case): both /usr/bin/python and /usr/bin/python3 are 3.x

Without your patch 1. is handled ok, and 2. not. With your patch vice versa.

cd /thrift/src/lib/java && /thrift/src/lib/java/gradlew assemble --console=plain --no-daemon -Prelease=true -Pthrift.version=0.14.0 -Pbuild.dir=/thrift/src/cmake_build/lib/java/build

I'm just using Ubuntu (bionic) in a docker container. After firing up the container, run
```
apt update
apt install python3
```
Install minimal dependencies of thrift (e.g. build-essential autoconf automake pkg-config libtool, flex, bison, git, etc). Then check out the sources and build.

@cfriedt: #2055 contains new version of the code. I made two if's: if $python is 2 then search for $python3; and if $python is 3 then $python3 = $python and have_py3="yes"

Now there's code that should always execute under python2... another can of worms :)
Now it seems OK. Some netstd tls feature failure.

I made a couple changes that might be unpopular but worth doing IMO:

1) Added benchmark project. This was to isolate the changes in order to more accurately measure the performance. Can be built upon in the future to measure other things.
2) Multi-target .NET Standard 2.1 on the Thrift library to access the ReadAsync ValueTask Stream API additions. Greatly reduces allocations performing reads when .NET Standard 2.1 is available (netcoreapp3+).

### .NET 4.8 Benchmarks
``` ini

BenchmarkDotNet=v0.12.0, OS=Windows 10.0.18363
Intel Core i9-9880H CPU 2.30GHz, 1 CPU, 16 logical and 8 physical cores
  [Host]     : .NET Framework 4.8 (4.8.4150.0), X64 RyuJIT
  DefaultJob : .NET Framework 4.8 (4.8.4150.0), X64 RyuJIT


```
|      Method | NumberOfOperationsPerIteration |     Mean |     Error |    StdDev |    Gen 0 | Gen 1 | Gen 2 | Allocated |
|------------ |------------------------------- |---------:|----------:|----------:|---------:|------:|------:|----------:|
| WriteString |                          10000 | 2.920 ms | 0.0581 ms | 0.0714 ms |  74.2188 |     - |     - | 470.15 KB |
|  ReadString |                          10000 | 5.939 ms | 0.1166 ms | 0.1780 ms | 367.1875 |     - |     - | 2272.4 KB |

After:
``` ini

BenchmarkDotNet=v0.12.0, OS=Windows 10.0.18363
Intel Core i9-9880H CPU 2.30GHz, 1 CPU, 16 logical and 8 physical cores
  [Host]     : .NET Framework 4.8 (4.8.4150.0), X64 RyuJIT
  DefaultJob : .NET Framework 4.8 (4.8.4150.0), X64 RyuJIT

Done âœ…
@Jens-G ,  done.

> IIRC this will break then compatibility with NET Framework. That's why we reset it to 2.0.

Your recall is 100% spot-on, that's why I didn't _change_ the target, I _added_ one. Subtle, but important difference. The library is now targetting .NET Standard 2.0 & .NET Standard 2.1 at the same time. When you compile you get 2 DLLs, one for each. Both can be included in the NuGet and then consumers can use whichever they support.

You can see this right now in practice in the Benchmark project. It is a Console app (EXE) multi-targeting .NET Framework 4.8 and .NET Core 3.1. When compiled, two exes. One will use the .NET Standard 2.0 path and the other .NET Standard 2.1.

The idea being, we support people on older versions but if you are using .NET Core 3+, we can take advantage of the performance improvements available.
